Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS: Systematics of Paleotropical grammitid ferns (Polypodiaceae): using phylogenies to resolve generic circumscriptions and explore the evolution of morphological characters
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Hawai'i at Manoa to study the evolution and diversity of grammitid ferns, with a focus on tropical Asia and islands of the Pacific. Grammitid ferns comprise a significant component of the vascular epiphyte flora in forested ecosystems in the Paleotropics, especially at higher elevations; however, further research is hindered by the lack of clearly defined generic boundaries. The proposed research will conduct new molecular and morphological analyses of the Paleotropical grammitid ferns to elucidate their evolutionary history. Resulting hypotheses of relationships will be used to elucidate generic boundaries, defining genera by discrete morphological characters. This work will also undertake appropriate taxonomic revisions. Hypotheses of relationships will be used to explore the evolution of morphological characters and to test for correlations between changes in growth habit and changes in morphology across species, as well as to test biogeographical hypotheses that relate to possible mechanisms of speciation.

The proposed research will be broadly beneficial to society because it will resolve classification problems that are an impediment to other research efforts and conservation management. The proposed research will advance the discovery and understanding of diversity of grammitid ferns and, thus, add to our knowledge of the evolution of vascular plants. The project will involve international collaboration among scientists, provide critical postdoctoral training to a recent PhD graduate, as well as doctoral training to a graduate student and research experience for undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the evolutionary relationships among species of grammitid ferns from Paleotropical regions (for example, Asia, Malaysia, Indonesia). The greatest diversity within this group occurs in the Paleotropics where there are an estimated 560 species compared to the Neotropics (the Americas) with ca. 300 species. We collected samples of over half of these species across a broad range of geographical distributions and environmental gradients. By generating and analyzing DNA sequences and variation in morphological attributes of the species we were able to: 1) better estimate the genealogical relationships of species and groups of species; 2) make robust hypotheses about the migration of species over time across the globe; and 3) gain a better understanding of the relationships between morphological variation and ecological conditions within and across species. For example, we discovered that the species of grammitid ferns native to Africa and Madagascar are closest relatives to species from the Americas, rather than from other areas of the Old World, which was counter to our expectations. We also found that new species tend to evolve at higher rates after the colonization of novel habitats compared to expansion into habitats that were similar to those previously occupied.

The project provided critical professional training for one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduate students, all of whom have moved on to professional employment or graduate school. The project also has made major contributions to a publically accessible website devoted to providing information about ferns globally, including the availability of an electronic identification key for the groups of grammitid ferns: http://www.fernsoftheworld.com/ .
